t: Habakkuk 3
Habakkuk’s Prayer
A*p prayer of Habakkuk the prophet, according to Shigionoth.
O*pn Lord,*s I have heard the report of you, and*ld your work, O Lord,*s do I fear. In*ln the midst of the years revive it; in*ld the midst of the years make it known; in*ld wrath remember mercy.
God*ln came from Teman, and*ld the Holy One from Mount Paran. Selah*ig His*ln splendor covered the heavens, and*ld the earth was full of his praise.
His*ln brightness was like the light; rays*ld flashed from his hand; and*ld there he veiled his power.
Before*ln him went pestilence, and*ld plague followed at his heels.
He*ln stood and measured the earth; he*ld looked and shook the nations; then*ln the eternal mountains were scattered; the*ld everlasting hills sank low. His*ld were the everlasting ways.
I*ln saw the tents of Cushan in affliction; the*ld curtains of the land of Midian did tremble.
Was*ln your wrath against the rivers, O Lord?*s Was*ld your anger against the rivers, or*ld your indignation against the sea, when*ln you rode on your horses, on*ld your chariot of salvation?
You*ln stripped the sheath from your bow, calling*ld for many arrows. Selah*ig You*ld split the earth with rivers.
The*ln mountains saw you and writhed; the*ld raging waters swept on; the*ln deep gave forth its voice; it*ld lifted its hands on high.
The*ln sun and moon stood still in their place at*ld the light of your arrows as they sped, at*ld the flash of your glittering spear.
You*ln marched through the earth in fury; you*ld threshed the nations in anger.
You*ln went out for the salvation of your people, for*ld the salvation of your anointed. You*ln crushed the head of the house of the wicked, laying*ld him bare from thigh to neck. Selah*ig
You*ln pierced with his own arrows the heads of his warriors, who*ld came like a whirlwind to scatter me, rejoicing*ld as if to devour the poor in secret.
You*ln trampled the sea with your horses, the*ld surging of mighty waters.

I*pn hear, and my body trembles; my*ld lips quiver at the sound; rottenness*ln enters into my bones; my*ld legs tremble beneath me. Yet*ln I will quietly wait for the day of trouble to*ld come upon people who invade us.
Habakkuk Rejoices in the Lord

Though*pn the fig tree should not blossom, nor*ld fruit be on the vines, the*ln produce of the olive fail and*ld the fields yield no food, the*ln flock be cut off from the fold and*ld there be no herd in the stalls,
yet*ln I will rejoice in the Lord;*s I*ld will take joy in the God of my salvation.
God,*sln the Lord, is my strength; he*ld makes my feet like the deer’s; he*ld makes me tread on my high places. To*pn the choirmaster: with stringed instruments.
